overview: The purpose of this part is to make various amendments to the medical use of cannabis and medical cannabis dispensaries laws by authorizing the department of health to inspect a qualifying patient's medical records, amending definitions, and clarifying conditions of use. [16] [16] This measure authorizes the sale of hemp products and accessories to the medical use of cannabis at retail dispensing locations, except in the waiting room. [16] It also authorizes expenditures from the Medical Cannabis Registry and Regulation Special Fund to fund programs for the mitigation and abatement of nuisances related to illegal cannabis and hemp products and medical cannabis dispensaries. [16]
appropriations: There is appropriated out of the medical cannabis registry and regulation special fund the sum of $750,000 (HB302_CD1_.HTM.txt) or so much thereof as may be necessary for fiscal year 2025-2026 and the same sum or so much thereof as may be necessary for fiscal year 2026-2027. [CHUNK_81, NUMBER_0] These funds are for the department of the attorney general to enforce, and mitigate nuisances relating to, illegal cannabis and hemp products and chapter 329D, Hawaii Revised Statutes. [16] The appropriation is also to establish, recruit, and hire four full-time equivalent (4.0 FTE) investigator V positions, one full-time equivalent (1.0 FTE) investigator IV position, and one full-time equivalent (1.0 FTE) analyst position. [16] [16]
agency_impact: The department of health may inspect a qualifying patient's medical records held by the physician, advanced practice registered nurse, or hospice provider who issued a written certification for the qualifying patient. [16] The department may suspend or revoke the ability to issue a written certification for any provider who refuses inspection or whose medical records do not comply with the requirements of this chapter. [16] [16] The purpose of the drug nuisance abatement unit is amended to include enforcement and prosecution of violations of chapter 329D. [16]
policy_impact: A bona fide physician-patient relationship or bona fide advanced practice registered nurse-patient relationship may be established via telehealth without requiring an initial in-person consultation. [16] [16] Any fees assessed by a certifying physician or advanced practice registered nurse to issue a written certification shall not exceed an amount equal to three times the amount of the fee charged by the department of health to issue a registration certificate. [16] The measure authorizes expenditures from the medical cannabis registry and regulation special fund to fund programs for the mitigation and abatement of nuisances relating to illegal cannabis and hemp products and chapter 329D. [16] [16]
revenue_sources: The measure authorizes expenditures from the Medical Cannabis Registry and Regulation Special Fund to fund programs for the mitigation and abatement of nuisances related to illegal cannabis and hemp products and medical cannabis dispensaries. six_year_fiscal_implications: The bill appropriates out of the medical cannabis registry and regulation special fund the sum of $750,000 (HB302_CD1_.HTM.txt) for fiscal year 2025-2026 and the same sum for fiscal year 2026-2027. [CHUNK_81, NUMBER_0] The appropriation is for the department of the attorney general to establish, recruit, and hire four investigator V positions, one investigator IV position, and one analyst position. [16] [16] The bill establishes criminal penalties for the unlicensed operation of a medical cannabis dispensary beginning July 1, 2025, rather than January 1, 2027. [17] The prohibition on cultivating cannabis without a cannabis cultivator license issued by the Department of Health will now begin on January 1, 2028, rather than January 1, 2027. [17] The Act shall take effect on July 1, 2025, with Part IV taking effect on January 1, 2028. [16]
updates_from_previous_fiscal_note: This version of the measure authorizes the Department of Health to inspect a qualifying patient's medical records held by the certifying provider and adds a definition for 'primary treating medical provider'. [17] [17] It authorizes the establishment of a provider-patient relationship via telehealth without requiring an initial in-person consultation and limits the maximum fee for issuing a written certification. [17] A new appropriation of $750,000 (HB302_CD1_CCR255_.htm.txt) from the Medical Cannabis Registry and Regulation Special Fund is inserted for nuisance abatement, including the establishment of six positions in the Attorney General's office. [CHUNK_108, NUMBER_1] The use of the special fund is expanded to include nuisances related to illegal cannabis and hemp products. [17] The effective date for criminal penalties for unlicensed dispensaries is moved to July 1, 2025, from January 1, 2027, while the effective date for requiring cultivator licenses is moved to January 1, 2028, from January 1, 2027.
